bingo package¶

Submodules¶

bingo.AGraph module¶

This module contains most of the code necessary for the representation of an acyclic graph (linear stack) in symbolic regression

class bingo.AGraph.AGNodes¶

Bases: object

class that contains node types used in acyclic graphs

bingo.AGraphCpp module¶

This module contains most of the code necessary for the representation of an acyclic graph (linear stack) in symbolic regression. This version of the Acyclic graph utilizes the bingocpp C++ library to do the function and derivative evaluations

The current implementation has many hard coded sections. At the moment an integer to operator mapping is how the command stack is parsed. the current map is: 0: load column of X 1: load constant 2: + addition 3: - subtraction 4: * multiplication 5: / division (currently not divide-by-zero protected) 6: sin 7: cos 8: exp 9: log 10: pow 11: abs 12: sqrt

class bingo.AGraphCpp.AGraphCpp¶

bingo.CoevolutionIsland module¶

Defines an island that has 3 populations and performs the simultaneous evolution of a main population, and a fitness predictor population. The third population is a set of training individuals on which the quality of the fitness predictors is judged. This is loosely based on the work of Schmidt and Lipson 2008?

class bingo.CoevolutionIsland.CoevolutionIsland(solution_training_data, solution_manipulator, predictor_manipulator, fitness_metric, solution_pop_size=64, solution_cx=0.7, solution_mut=0.01, solution_age_fitness=False, predictor_pop_size=16, predictor_cx=0.5, predictor_mut=0.1, predictor_ratio=0.1, predictor_update_freq=50, trainer_pop_size=16, trainer_update_freq=50, verbose=False)¶

Bases: object

Coevolution island with 3 populations solution_pop: the solutions to symbolic regression predictor_pop: sub sampling trainers: population of solutions which are used to train the predictors

Parameters:
  • solution_training_data – training data that is used in the evaluation of fitness of the solution population
  • solution_manipulator – a gene manipulator for the symbolic regression solution population
  • predictor_manipulator – a gene manipulator for the fitness predictor population
  • solution_pop_size – size of the solution population
  • solution_cx – crossover probability for the solution population
  • solution_mut – mutation probability for the solution population
  • predictor_pop_size – size of the fitness predictor population
  • predictor_cx – crossover probability for the fitness predictor population
  • predictor_mut – mutation probability for the fitness predictor population
  • predictor_ratio – approximate ratio of time spent on fitness predictor calculations and the total computation time
  • predictor_update_freq – number of generations of the solution population after which the fitness predictor is updated
  • trainer_pop_size – size of the trainer population
  • trainer_update_freq – number of generations of the solution population after which a new trainer is added to the trainer population
  • required_params – number of unique parameters that are required in implicit (constant) symbolic regression
  • verbose – True for extra output printed to screen
add_new_trainer()¶

Add/replace trainer to current trainer population. The trainer which maximizes discrepancy between fitness predictors is chosen

dump_populations(s_subset=None, p_subset=None, t_subset=None, with_removal=False)¶

Dump the 3 populations to a pickleable object (tuple of lists)

Parameters:
  • s_subset – list of indices for the subset of the solution population which is dumped. A None value results in all of the population being dumped.
  • p_subset – list of indices for the subset of the fitness predictor population which is dumped. A None value results in all of the population being dumped.
  • t_subset – list of indices for the subset of the trainer population which is dumped. A None value results in all of the population being dumped.
  • with_removal – boolean describing whether the elements should be removed from population after dumping
Returns:

tuple of lists of populations
generational_step()¶

generational step for solution population, This function takes the necessary steps for the other populations to maintain desired predictor/solution computation ratio

load_populations(pop_lists, replace=True)¶

load 3 populations from pickleable object

Parameters:
  • pop_lists – tuple of lists of the 3 populations
  • replace – default (True) value results in all of the population being loaded/replaced. False value means that the population in pop_list is appended to the current population
predictor_fitness(predictor)¶

Fitness function for predictor population, based on the ability to accurately describe the true fitness of the trainer population

Parameters:predictor – predictor for which the fitness is assessed
Returns:fitness
print_trainers()¶

For debugging: print trainers to screen

solution_fitness_est(solution)¶

Estimated fitness for solution pop based on the best predictor

Parameters:solution – individual of the solution population for which the fitness will be calculated
Returns:fitness, complexity
solution_fitness_true(solution)¶

full calculation of fitness for solution population

Parameters:solution – individual of the solution population for which the fitness will be calculated
Returns:fitness
true_fitness_plus_complexity(solution)¶

Gets the true (full) fitness and complexity of a solution individual

Parameters:solution – individual of the solution population for which the fitness will be calculated
Returns:fitness, complexity
use_true_fitness()¶

Sets the fitness function for the solution population to the true (full) fitness rather than using a fitness predictor.

bingo.FitnessMetric module¶

This module encapsulates different fitness metrics that can be used for symbolic regression in bingo

class bingo.FitnessMetric.FitnessMetric¶

Bases: object

fitness metric superclass

evaluate_fitness(individual, training_data)¶

Evaluate the fitness of an individual and optimize it if necessary :param individual: an AGraph-like individual to be evaluated :param training_data: ExplicitTrainingData :return fitness of the individual

evaluate_fitness_vector(individual, training_data)¶

returns the fitness vector of an individual using a given set of training data :param individual: a gene to be evaluated :param training_data: the data used by the fitness metric :return: fitness vector

optimize_constants(individual, training_data)¶

perform levenberg-marquardt optimization on embedded constants :param individual: a gene to be evaluated :param training_data: the data used by the fitness metric

class bingo.FitnessMetric.ImplicitRegression(required_params=None, normalize_dot=False, acceptable_nans=0.1)¶

Bases: bingo.FitnessMetric.FitnessMetric

Implicit Regression, version 2

evaluate_fitness(individual, training_data)¶

Fitness of this metric is related cos of angle between between df_dx and dx_dt. Different normalization and erorr checking are available.

Parameters:
  • individual – an AGraph-like individual to be evaluated
  • training_data – ImplicitTrainingData
Returns:

the mean of the fitness vector, ignoring nans
evaluate_fitness_vector(individual, training_data)¶

Fitness of this metric is related cos of angle between between df_dx and dx_dt. Different normalization and erorr checking are available.

Parameters:
  • individual – an AGraph-like individual to be evaluated
  • training_data – ImplicitTrainingData
Returns:

fitness vector

evaluate_fitness_vector(individual, training_data)¶

from schmidt and lipson’s papers

Parameters:

  • training_data – ImplicitTrainingData
Returns:

the fitness for each row
class bingo.FitnessMetric.PairwiseAtomicPotential¶

Bases: bingo.FitnessMetric.FitnessMetric

Pairwise atomic potential which is fit with total potential energy for a set of configurations

evaluate_fitness_vector(individual, training_data)¶

Fitness is calculated as how well total potential energies are matched by the summation of pairwise energies which are calculated by the individual fitness = sum( f(r_i) ) - U_true for i in config

Parameters:
  • individual – an AGraph-like individual to be evaluated
  • training_data – ImplicitTrainingData
Returns:

the fitness for each row
class bingo.FitnessMetric.StandardRegression(const_deriv=False)¶

Bases: bingo.FitnessMetric.FitnessMetric

Traditional fitness evaluation

evaluate_fit_vec_w_const_deriv(individual, training_data)¶

returns the fitness vector and its derivatove with respect any included constantsof an individual using a given set of training data :param individual: a gene to be evaluated :param training_data: the data used by the fitness metric :return: fitness vector, dfitness/dconstants array

evaluate_fitness_vector(individual, training_data)¶

fitness vector = f(x) - y where f is defined by the individual and x, y are in the training data :param individual: an AGraph-like individual to be evaluated :param training_data: ExplicitTrainingData :return fitness vector

optimize_constants(individual, training_data)¶

perform levenberg-marquardt optimization on embedded constants :param individual: a gene to be evaluated :param training_data: the data used by the fitness metric

bingo.FitnessPredictor module¶

This module contains most of the code necessary for the representation of an fitness predictor in the form of a subsampling list for real data

bingo.Island module¶

This module contains the code for an island in an island-based GA optimization it is general enough to work on any representation/fitness

dominate(indv1, indv2)¶

Returns whether or not individual1 dominates individual 2 in all their fitness measures: i.e. True if all values in indv1.fitness tuple are less than or equal to the counterpart in individual 2 else False

Parameters:
  • indv1 – first individual with fitness member
  • indv2 – second individual with fitness member
Returns:

Does indv1 dominate indv2 (boolean)

bingo.IslandManager module¶

Island managers manage a group of coevolution islands. Specifically, they step through generations, coordinate migration, and test convergence. Currently there are two implementations: ParallelIslandManger which runs islands on individual processors using mpi, and SerialIslandManager which runs islands one after one on a single processor

class bingo.IslandManager.IslandManager(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: object

IslandManager is an abstract class used for making controllers of groups of coevolution islands

static assign_send_receive(pop_size1, pop_size2)¶

Assign indices for exchange through random shuffling

Parameters:pop_size – number of individuals in the populations which will be exchanged (must be equal in population size)
Returns:the indices that each island will be swapping
do_final_plots(make_plots)¶

Makes some summary output

Parameters:make_plots – boolean for whether to produce plots
do_migration()¶

Coordinates migration between islands

do_steps(n_steps, **kwargs)¶

Steps through generations.

Parameters:
  • n_steps – number of generations through which to step
  • kwargs – extra keyword args that can be passed (implementation specific)
load_state(filename)¶

loads island manager information from file

Parameters:filename – full name of file to load pickle
run_islands(max_steps, epsilon, min_steps=0, step_increment=1000, make_plots=True, checkpoint_file=None, **do_steps_kwargs)¶

Runs co-evolution islands until convergence of best solution

Parameters:
  • max_steps – maximum number of steps to take
  • epsilon – error which defines convergence
  • min_steps – minimum number of steps to take
  • step_increment – the number of steps between migrations/convergence checks
  • make_plots – boolean for whether to produce plots
  • checkpoint_file – base file name for checkpoint files
  • do_steps_kwargs – extra keyword arguments are passed through to do_steps()
Return converged:
 

whether a converged solution has been found
save_state(filename)¶

Saves all information in the sim

Parameters:filename – full name of file to save pickle
test_convergence(epsilon, make_plots)¶

Tests for convergence of the island system

Parameters:
  • epsilon – error which defines convergence
  • make_plots – boolean for whether to produce plots
Returns:

boolean for whether convergence has been reached
class bingo.IslandManager.ParallelIslandManager(restart_file=None, *args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: bingo.IslandManager.IslandManager

ParallelIslandManager is an implementation of the IslandManager class which uses mpi4py and message passing to coordinate the distribution of coevolution islands in parallel

developer notes:

MPI_Tag Function
0 average age sent from rank 0 (i.e., avg step limit exceeded)
2 age uptate sent to rank 0
4 migration communications
6 saving state
7 loading state
do_final_plots(make_plots)¶

Parameters:make_plots – boolean for whether to produce plots

Steps through generations

Parameters:
  • n_steps – number of generations through which to step
  • non_block – boolean to determine blocking or non
  • when_update – how often each rank updates in non blocking

This module contains the functions for general plotting purposes

  • Y – true solution
  • eval_func – evaluation function to get y_estimated as function of X
  • file_name – desired output filename

  • file_name – desired output file name

bingo.SimpleGp module¶

This module is meant to provide a wrapper to some of the core bingo components that hides a lot of the complexity.

class bingo.SimpleGp.SimpleGp(building_blocks, fitness_metric, population_size, data, var_names, complexity=16, fp_complexity=32)¶

Bases: object

SimpleGP is a class that wraps some of the functionality of bingo into a simple tool that can be used for education or illustration. Currently it is limited to explicit and implicit regression and uses the full-python AGraph.

evolve(n_generations=1)¶

Let the simple gp equations evolve a set number of genrations

Parameters:n_generations – the number of generations to evolve
get_best_individual()¶

Gets the best equation in the simple gp population

Returns:fitness and string of the best individual

Parameters:x_eval – X at which to evaluate the functions
Returns:list of n_pop lists of [x, y, fitness, label]

Converts the individual to a simple string equation that can be parsed with sympy then simplified

Parameters:indv – the individual to be converted to string representation
Returns:string of equation of individual

bingo.TrainingData module¶

This module contains the definition of various data containers that store training data for bingo.

class bingo.TrainingData.ExplicitTrainingData(x, y)¶

Bases: bingo.TrainingData.TrainingData

ExplicitTrainingData: Training data of this type contains an input array of data (x) and an output array of data (y). Both must be 2 dimensional numpy arrays

size()¶

gets the length of the first dimension of the data :return: indexable size

class bingo.TrainingData.ImplicitTrainingData(x, dx_dt=None)¶

Bases: bingo.TrainingData.TrainingData

ImplicitTrainingData: Training data of this type contains an input array of data (x) and its time derivative (dx_dt). Both must be 2 dimensional numpy arrays

size()¶

gets the length of the first dimension of the data :return: indexable size

class bingo.TrainingData.PairwiseAtomicTrainingData(potential_energy, configurations=None, r_list=None, config_lims_r=None)¶

Bases: bingo.TrainingData.TrainingData

PairwiseAtomicTrainingData: Training data of this type contains distances (r) between ataoms in several configurations. each configuration has an associated potential energy. The r values beloning to each configuration are bounded by configuration limits (config_lims_r)

size()¶

gets the number of configurations :return: indexable size

class bingo.TrainingData.TrainingData¶

Bases: object

Training Data superclass which defines the methods needed for derived classes

size()¶

gets the number of indexable points in the training data :return: size of the training dataset

bingo.Utils module¶

Utils contains useful utility functions for doing and testing symbolic regression problems in the bingo package

bingo.Utils.calculate_partials(X)¶

Calculate derivatves with respect to time (first dimension).

Parameters:X – 2d numpy array in for which derivatives will be calculated in the first diminsion. Distinct trajectories can be specified by separating the datasets within X by rows of np.nan
Returns:updated X array and corresponding time derivatives
bingo.Utils.savitzky_golay(y, window_size, order, deriv=0, rate=1)¶

Smooth (and optionally differentiate) data with a Savitzky-Golay filter The Savitzky-Golay filter removes high frequency noise from data. It has the advantage of preserving the original shape and features of the signal better than other types of filtering approaches, such as moving averages techniques.

The Savitzky-Golay is a type of low-pass filter, particularly suited for smoothing noisy data. The main idea behind this approach is to make for each point a least-square fit with a polynomial of high order over a odd-sized window centered at the point.

[1]A. Savitzky, M. J. E. Golay, Smoothing and Differentiation of Data by Simplified Least Squares Procedures. Analytical Chemistry, 1964, 36 (8), pp 1627-1639.
[2]Numerical Recipes 3rd Edition: The Art of Scientific Computing W.H. Press, S.A. Teukolsky, W.T. Vetterling, B.P. Flannery Cambridge University Press ISBN-13: 9780521880688
Parameters:
  • y – array_like, shape (N,) the values of the time history of the signal.
  • window_size – int the length of the window. Must be an odd integer number.
  • order – int the order of the polynomial used in the filtering. Must be less then window_size - 1.
  • deriv – int the order of the derivative to compute (default = 0 means only smoothing)
Returns:

ys : ndarray, shape (N) the smoothed signal (or it’s n-th derivative).
bingo.Utils.savitzky_golay_gram(y, window_size, order, deriv=0)¶

Smooth (and optionally differentiate) data with a Savitzky-Golay filter The Savitzky-Golay filter removes high frequency noise from data. It has the advantage of preserving the original shape and features of the signal better than other types of filtering approaches, such as moving averages techniques.

The Savitzky-Golay is a type of low-pass filter, particularly suited for smoothing noisy data. The main idea behind this approach is to make for each point a least-square fit with a polynomial of high order over a odd-sized window centered at the point.

A Gram polynomial version of this is used to have better estimates near the boundaries of the data.

[3]P.A. Gorry, General Least-Squares Smoothing and Differentiation by the Convolution (Savitzky-Golay) Method. Analytical Chemistry, 1990, 62, pp 570-573
Parameters:
  • y – array_like, shape (N,) the values of the time history of the signal.
  • window_size – int the length of the window. Must be an odd integer number.
  • order – int the order of the polynomial used in the filtering. Must be less then window_size - 1.
  • deriv – int the order of the derivative to compute (default = 0 means only smoothing)
Returns:

ys : ndarray, shape (N) the smoothed signal (or it’s n-th derivative).
bingo.Utils.snake_walk()¶

Generates 2-d dataset which looks like a snake wiggling back and forth

Returns:2d numpy array for data
